newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai T-bill repo rates end up, spots down.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai T-bill repo rates end up, spots down.

text.p: -- Contracts on the treasury bill repurchase market in Shanghai closed up across the board on Wednesday, with turnover falling to 6.11 million lots from 9.78 million on Tuesday.
The annual rate for the shortest three-day contract ended up at 15.20 percent from 13.00 and the most active seven-day contract closed slightly up at 10.15 percent from 10.10.
One lot is 1,000 yuan face value of treasury bills.
Traders said the rises today were mainly due to a rising domestic A share market. The A share index closed up 1.25 percent at 832.926 points today after a few days of losses.
"Many investors expect the A market to continue a rally in the next few days," a trader said. "Some institutions took money out of the repo market today, pushing up the rates."
Most contracts on the T-bill spot market in Shanghai closed down on Monday on a technical correction after surges in the past few days, traders said.
The most active three-year bond maturing in August 1999, which made its debut yesterday, fell to 105.50 yuan from 105.86 on profit-taking after a surge on the first day of trading.
Combined market volume shrank to 4.64 million lots from 12.1 million. -- Shanghai newsroom (86-21) 6279-7004
